newsitem.title: INDIA: SAS Institute targets India's top 100 companies.
newsitem.headline: SAS Institute targets India's top 100 companies.

text.p: SAS Institute, a private U.S.-based software company, on Friday announced the launch of its Bombay liaison office and said it was targeting the Indian financial, telcommunications and manufacturing sectors.
"Our vision is quite long term in India," Rohini Midha, SAS's India country manager said at a news conference in Bombay.
SAS, which currently counts revenues of about $150,000-200,000 per year from Indian customers, hopes its earning power in India will take off in the next few years, Midha said.
"We expect to increase our revenue at least five-fold in the next three years," she said.
SAS will target the top 100 Indian companies, Midha added.

SAS Institute, based in North Carolina, is among the top global companies in end-to-end solutions for data warehousing and data mining. SAS software includes capabilities and tools for data warehousing including managing, organising and exploiting the warehouse.
"By partnering with Indian consultants, we will provide Indian companies with the ability to make better business decisions based upon data, rather than guess-work," Midha said.

The firm has over 55 Indian customers which include the Reserve Bank of India, BPL Ltd., Tata Iron & Steel Company and Standard Chartered Bank who are served through Tata Consultancy Services, SAS's Indian distributor since 1991.
SAS software is being used at 30,000 business, government and university sites in the world.

"The office has been opened to provide better support to our current Indian customers and further address the marketing and sales needs of the Indian market," said Lee Richardson, SAS's director of Asia Pacific operations.

SAS Institute earned worldwide revenues of $653 million in 1996, officials said. The firm has a direct presence in 39 countries and is represented in 16 other countries through distributor alliances, they said.
